title: Customer Segmentation Made Simple: K-Means in Python
text:
Ever wonder how companies like Spotify recommend playlists or how stores know which coupons to send you? Customer segmentation is the key. In this tutorial, we‚Äôll walk through how to use K-Means clustering in Python to group customers into meaningful segments.
By the end, you‚Äôll know how to:

title: Customer Segmentation Made Simple: K-Means in Python
text:
Why Customer Segmentation Matters
Businesses rarely treat all customers the same. Instead, they group customers into segments based on characteristics like age, spending, or habits. This allows for:

Personalized marketing (ads that feel relevant, not random)
Smarter product design (different products for different groups)
Better resource allocation (focus on high-value customers)

And the cool part? You don‚Äôt need dozens of variables to see interesting patterns. Sometimes just age and annual spending are enough to show natural groupings.

title: Customer Segmentation Made Simple: K-Means in Python
text:
Step 1: Load the Data
Let‚Äôs start with a simple dataset of fictional customers:


Code
import pandas as pd

# Sample dataset
data = {
    "CustomerID": [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6],
    "Age": [19, 35, 26, 27, 50, 45],
    "AnnualSpend": [15_000, 35_000, 18_000, 22_000, 55_000, 48_000]
}

df = pd.DataFrame(data)

title: Customer Segmentation Made Simple: K-Means in Python
text:
Step 2: Run K-Means
We‚Äôll use scikit-learn‚Äôs implementation of K-Means.


Code
from sklearn.cluster import KMeans

X = df[["Age", "AnnualSpend"]]

# Create a KMeans model with 2 clusters
kmeans = KMeans(n_clusters=2, random_state=42)
df["Cluster"] = kmeans.fit_predict(X)

print(df)


   CustomerID  Age  AnnualSpend  Cluster
0           1   19        15000        0
1           2   35        35000        1
2           3   26        18000        0
3           4   27        22000        0
4           5   50        55000        1
5           6   45        48000        1


Now each customer has a cluster label indicating their segment.

title: Customer Segmentation Made Simple: K-Means in Python
text:
Step 3: Visualize the Clusters
A scatterplot helps us see how the groups form.


Code
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.scatter(df["Age"], df["AnnualSpend"], c=df["Cluster"], cmap="viridis", s=100)
plt.xlabel("Age")
plt.ylabel("Annual Spending ($)")
plt.title("Customer Segments (K-Means)")
plt.show()









Tip: Each color shows a different segment. Try changing n_clusters to 3 or 4 and see how the picture changes.
Example visualization: 
Alt text: Scatterplot with customers grouped into two clusters by spending and age.

title: Customer Segmentation Made Simple: K-Means in Python
text:
Step 4: Interpret the Cluster Centers
K-Means calculates cluster centers (the ‚Äúaverage‚Äù customer in each group).


Code
centers = pd.DataFrame(kmeans.cluster_centers_, columns=["Age", "AnnualSpend"])
print(centers)


         Age   AnnualSpend
0  24.000000  18333.333333
1  43.333333  46000.000000


This tells a clear story:

Cluster 0 ‚Üí Younger customers with lower spending
Cluster 1 ‚Üí Older customers with higher spending

title: Customer Segmentation Made Simple: K-Means in Python
text:
Wrapping Up
K-Means gives us a quick, data-driven way to segment customers. Even with just two variables, we can uncover meaningful groups that businesses can target differently.

title: Customer Segmentation Made Simple: K-Means in Python
text:
Call to Action
Now that you‚Äôve seen how simple customer segmentation can be, try it yourself!

Use a different dataset‚Äîlike survey responses, your Spotify listening habits, or even your classmates‚Äô study hours.
Experiment with different numbers of clusters (n_clusters).
Share your visualization with a peer and explain what the groups might mean.

For further reading, check out the scikit-learn K-Means documentation.
